raw_text:
Greek pair attend drugs hearing
 
 Greek sprinters Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou have appeared before an independent tribunal which will decide if their bans should stand.
 
 They were given provisional suspensions by athletics' ruling body the IAAF in December for failing to take drugs tests before the Athens Olympics. The pair arrived with former coach Christos Tzekos to give evidence at the Hellenic Olympic Committee's offices. A decision is expected to be announced before the end of February. Whatever the ruling, all parties will have the right to appeal to the Court of Arbitration for Sport. Yiannis Papadoyiannakis, who was head of the Greek Olympic team at the Athens Games last year, also testified at the tribunal, along with other Greek sports officials and athletes. "I believe the tribunal will reach a decision that will uphold the standing of the institution," said Papadoyiannakis. "Whatever the athletes have done, we must not forget that they have offered us great moments." Kenteris won 200m gold at the 2000 Sydney Olympics, while Thanou won silver in the 100m.
 
 They withdrew from the Athens Games last August after missing drugs tests on the eve of the opening ceremony. The pair spent four days in a hospital, claiming they had been injured in a motorcycle crash. The five-member tribunal, assembled by the Hellenic Association of Amateur Athletics, is also examining allegations that Kenteris and Thanou avoided tests in Tel Aviv and Chicago before the Games. Tzekos was also banned for two years by the IAAF. He faces charges of assisting in the use of prohibited substances and tampering with the doping inspection process. All three, who have repeatedly denied the allegations, have also been charged by a Greek prosecutor and face trial for doping-related charges. A trial date has not been set. In imposing two-year suspensions on the duo on 22 December, the IAAF described their explanations for missing the tests as "unacceptable". But Kenteris' lawyer Gregory Ioannidis told BBC Sport earlier this week he was confident the sprinters would be cleared of the charges of failing to give information on their location and refusing to submit to testing. "We refute both charges as unsubstantiated and illogical," he said. "There have been certain breaches in the correct application of the rules on behalf of the sporting authorities and their officials, and these procedural breaches have also violated my client's rights. "There is also evidence that proves the fact that my client has been persecuted."
llama3.2:1b: Greek sprinters Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou are before an independent tribunal to decide on provisional suspensions related to missing drugs tests during their participation in the Athens Olympics. They were given suspensions for failing to take tests, with a decision expected by the end of February. The tribunal is also examining allegations that they avoided testing in Tel Aviv and Chicago.
llama3.2:3b: Greek sprinters Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou attended a hearing before an independent tribunal to decide on their bans for failing to take drug tests before the Athens Olympics. The IAAF imposed two-year suspensions, but all parties have the right to appeal to the Court of Arbitration for Sport. Yiannis Papadoyiannakis testified that he believes the tribunal will uphold the institution's standing, while Kenteris' lawyer denies his clients were involved in doping and claim they are being persecuted.
gemma2:2b: Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou, Greek sprinters who missed drugs tests before the 2004 Athens Olympics, appeared before a tribunal to argue their case against provisional bans. The duo faces possible suspension and appeals if the Greek Olympic Committee tribunal finds them guilty.  The tribunal is also examining allegations of dodging testing in Tel Aviv and Chicago. Their former coach Christos Tzekos was also banned for two years. Kenteris' lawyer argues that his clients' justifications for missing tests are justified and their procedural rights were violated.
qwen2.5:0.5b: A Greek sprinters Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou were given provisional suspensions by athletics' ruling body the IAAF in December for failing to take drugs tests before the Athens Olympics. They are now being examined at a court of arbitration by the Hellenic Olympic Committee's offices. The court is expected to release their findings before February, and they will have the right to appeal. Kenteris won gold medals at the 2000 Sydney Olympics in 2001 and silver in the 100m at Athens Games in 2004. They withdrew from the Athens Games last August after missing drugs tests on the eve of the opening ceremony.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Greek sprinters Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou appear before an independent tribunal to decide whether they should keep their provisional bans from drug tests for Athens Olympics, with former coach Christos Tzekos among those testifying. Papadoyiannakis hopes the tribunal will uphold the institution's standing, while Kenteris' lawyer suggests the charges are unsubstantiated and illogical. The duo missed drugs tests due to a motorcycle crash earlier in the year and faces doping-related allegations for testing absentees from Tel Aviv and Chicago.
qwen2.5:3b: Greek sprinters Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou appeared before an independent tribunal to decide on the continuation of their bans for failing to take drugs tests prior to Athens Olympics. They are represented by former coach Christos Tzekos, who was also banned for two years. The tribunal will rule whether to uphold the IAAF's provisional suspensions or allow appeal through CAS. The pair won gold and silver medals in previous Olympics. They have denied allegations of avoiding tests in Tel Aviv and Chicago. A decision is expected before February; all parties can appeal.

Greek pair attend drugs hearing.

Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou have appeared before an independent tribunal which will decide if their bans should stand.

They were given provisional suspensions by athletics' ruling body the IAAF in December for failing to take drugs tests before the Athens Olympics. A decision is expected to be announced before the end of February.

All parties will have the right to appeal to the Court of Arbitration for Sport, Yiannis Papadoyiannakis, who was head of the Greek Olympic team at the Athens Games last year, along with other Greek sports officials and athletes.

Papadoyiannakis said "I believe the tribunal will reach a decision that will uphold the standing of the institution." Whatever the athletes have done, we must not forget that they have offered us great moments. Kenteris won 200m gold at the 2,000 Sydney Olympics, while Thanou won silver in the 100m.

They withdrew from the Athens Games last August after missing drugs tests on the eve of the opening ceremony. The pair spent four days in a hospital, claiming they had been injured in a motorcycle crash.
 
The five-member tribunal, assembled by the Hellenic Association of Amateur Athletics, is also examining allegations that Kenteris and Thanou avoided tests in Tel Aviv and Chicago before the Games.

Tzekos was banned for two years by the IAAF. He faces charges of assisting in the use of prohibited substances and tampering with the doping inspection process.

All three, who have repeatedly denied the allegations, have also been charged by a Greek prosecutor and face trial for doping-related charges. A trial date has not been set yet. In imposing two-year suspensions on the duo on 22 December, the IAAF described their explanations for missing the tests as "unacceptable". But Kenteris's lawyer Gregory Ioannidis told BBC Sport earlier this week he was confident the sprinters would be cleared of the charges of failing to give information on their location and refusing to submit to testing. "We refute both charges as unsubstantiated and illogical," he said. "There have been certain breaches in the correct application of the rules on behalf of the sporting authorities and their officials, and these procedural breaches have also violated my client's rights." There is also evidence that proves the fact that my client has been persecuted.

Greek sprinters Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou appeared before an independent tribunal to face drug test bans during the Athens Olympics after they had previously participated in doping-related activities at the 2000 Sydney Olympics. They were given provisional suspensions by the IAAF from their previous participation in international sports events, including the 2018 Greek Olympic Team. The pair withdrew from the Games due to medical complications and faced further investigations regarding drug use in Tel Aviv and Chicago before the event. A tribunal for sport examined allegations of drug testing for the opening ceremony and other events. All three individuals are subject to trials for doping-related charges, with a two-year suspension expected by the IAAF for their conduct.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Greek athletes Kostas Kenteri and Katerin Thanou appear before an independent tribunal to decide whether their bans should stand due to a provisionally suspended ban from using drugs. The four-member tribunal includes two Greek sports officials, three athletics' administrators and one athlete (Kenteri). The hearing is expected to last for several days, with the Athens Olympics set to be held soon. The Athens Games were delayed due to a motorcycle crash suffered by Kenteri and a subsequent hospitalization, which he claims was due to injuries sustained in a car accident before the Games. Charges of tampering with drug tests are also against Tzekos, who has repeatedly denied them but faces trial for alleged doping-related charges. The Athens Olympic Committee (IOC) and IAAF have already banned the pair for two years, and will likely face further charges as a result of their alleged failure to submit information on their location and refusing to submit to testing. Despite Kenteri's lawyer's statement that the sprinters would be cleared of the charges of failing to give information, Ioannidis expressed confidence in their innocence.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The Greek pair who are part of the Olympic sprinters' hearing in Athens this week include Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou, who attended a disciplinary tribunal by the International Association for Athletics Federation (IAAF). The pair arrived with their former coach Christos Tzekos to give evidence at the Hellenic Olympic Committee (HOC) offices. They have been given provisional suspensions due to failing drug tests before the Athens Olympics in 2016. This suspension has led to an investigation by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS). The Greek athletics community will have the right to appeal the decision to the CAS, while the IAAF will also face a trial and possible bans on their officials and sports officials if they are found guilty in this trial.
phi:2.7b: The Greek sprinters Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou appeared before an independent tribunal to determine if their drug bans should stand after failing to take tests before the Athens Olympics. The IAAF, athletics' ruling body, gave provisional suspensions to the pair in December for the same reason. All parties have the right to appeal to the Court of Arbitration for Sport. Yiannis Papadoyiannakis testified at the tribunal along with other Greek sports officials and athletes. Kenteris won 200m gold in Sydney while Thanou won silver in the 100m. They were disqualified from the Athens Games after missing drugs tests before the opening ceremony, but they claimed to have been injured in a motorcycle crash. The IAAF described their explanations as "unacceptable." The tribunal is examining allegations that Kenteris and Thanou avoided tests in Tel Aviv and Chicago before the Games. Tzekos was also banned for two years by the IAAF for assisting in the use of prohibited substances and tampering with the doping inspection process. All three have been charged by a Greek prosecutor and face trial for doping-related charges, but they deny all allegations. Kenteris' lawyer has said his client was persecuted.

They received provisional suspensions by athletics' ruling body the IAAF in December for failing to take drugs tests before the Athens Olympics. The pair were injured in a motorcycle crash and faced charges of avoiding tests in Tel Aviv and Chicago before the Games. All three, who have repeatedly denied the allegations, face trial for doping-related charges. A trial date has not been set. Whatever the ruling, all parties will have the right to appeal to the Court of Arbitration for Sport.

Greek prosecutor and a trial date have not been set as they face doping-related charges, with their lawyer stating there are breaches in rules and violations of clients' rights.
stablelm2:1.6b: Two-time Olympic gold medalists Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou appeared before an independent tribunal to face possible bans for failing to take drugs tests prior to the Athens Olympics. Their suspensions were initially given by athletics' ruling body, the IAAF, in December, but a hearing is expected to be announced by the end of February. Both Kenteris and Thanou testified at the tribunal with former coach Christos Tzekos, along with other Greek sports officials and athletes. If their bans stand, all parties will have the right  to appeal to the Court of Arbitration for Sport. The tribunal is also examining allegations that Kenteris and Thanou avoided tests in Tel Aviv and Chicago before the Games, with former coach Tzekos facing similar charges. Both Kenteris' lawyer and Tzekos deny the allegations, with the latter stating that he has been persecuted by the IAAF and his own officials.

The IAAF imposed these penalties in December after they missed mandatory pre-Olympic testing and claimed injury from a motorcycle crash. Kenteris won 200m gold at Sydney '00, while Thanou secured silver in the 100m. They withdrew from Athens '04 shortly after the opening ceremony. Testifying at the Hellenic Olympic Committee's offices were Kenteris' former coach Christos Tzekos (also banned for two years), other Greek sports officials, and athletes. The tribunal is investigating allegations of avoiding tests in Tel Aviv and Chicago. The IAAF considers their excuses "unacceptable," but Kenteris' lawyer asserts the charges are unfounded and that procedural breaches by authorities violated his client's rights. A decision is expected before February, with both parties retaining the right to appeal to the Court of Arbitration for Sport.
